header.title: Esoteric Extension of Tarot to Develop Supersensory Powers

central_thesis: The text posits that developing supersensory powers and manifesting desires is achieved through conscious direction of the subconscious mind, rooted in a clear understanding and focus on one's true wants, and integrated with a responsible, non-escapist approach to spiritual and material life.

structure_content.chapter_title: Lesson 4: Transcriptions from Ann Davies' Class Lectures
structure_content.summary: This lesson focuses on the esoteric aspects of desire and 'demonstration.' It emphasizes that true desire fulfillment stems from knowing oneself and one's consciousness, which is presented as an aspect of God. The core idea is that our present reality is a result of past thinking, feeling, and desiring. By becoming attentive to our wants and understanding how to direct them consciously, we become co-creators with God. The text differentiates true spirituality from mere renunciation or weariness with life, arguing that spirituality involves conscious participation in life's flow. It also highlights the importance of understanding the 'why' behind desires and the potential pitfalls of spiritual or mental inattention, especially for the occultist who can fall harder due to heightened sensitivity. The lesson advocates for conscious direction of subconscious powers to reverse destructive tendencies and achieve goals. It critiques escapist attitudes like 'all I want is spiritual illumination' and stresses the need for practical application and skill development, using the example of becoming a teacher. The text also redefines 'exhibitionism' as a universal trait that, when used constructively, allows for the expression of God's creative spirit. It cautions against superficial claims of mastery and emphasizes that true masters do not typically function as group teachers. The lesson concludes by stressing the importance of caring for the physical vehicle as the instrument through which consciousness experiences itself and of using creative subconscious energies for health and well-being as a foundation for spiritual growth.

key_concepts.definition: The ability to consciously direct one's thoughts, feelings, and desires to manifest desired outcomes, thereby participating with God in the creation of reality. This requires self-awareness and understanding of how one's internal state shapes external circumstances.

The authentic yearning of the individual, distinct from fleeting wants or material distractions. Discovering true desire is presented as a crucial first step toward self-fulfillment and alignment with the Primal Will to Good.
The process of manifesting desires into reality, not merely as a showy display of power but as a natural outcome of focused intent and conscious creation.

The powerful, underlying aspect of the mind that manifests our thoughts, feelings, and desires into our experienced reality. The text emphasizes learning to direct this consciously, rather than it operating automatically and often destructively.

The text critiques a solemn, detached, or renunciatory 'spiritual attitude,' arguing that true spirituality involves conscious, joyful participation in life, embracing the qualities of beauty and expression that are inherent in the divine.

The human body. The text stresses that this vehicle must be cared for through proper nourishment, exercise, and attention, as it is the instrument through which consciousness experiences itself and its environment. Neglecting the physical vehicle hinders spiritual development and the full utilization of subconscious powers.

A universal human trait, reframed as the natural divine impulse to display and express. When directed constructively, it aids in projecting oneself and one's message, essential for teaching or radiating one's essence.

practical_system.description: The practical system described involves a multi-step process for developing supersensory powers and manifesting desires. It begins with intense self-inquiry to identify true desires ('What do I want?' and 'WHY?'). This is followed by a deep understanding of how past thoughts, feelings, and desires have shaped current reality, thereby fostering self-awareness. The core operative technique is the conscious direction of the creative subconsciousness towards specific goals. This requires maintaining focus, analyzing one's thoughts and emotions concerning the goal, and transmuting any disharmonious elements. The system also mandates the care and enhancement of the physical vehicle (body) as an essential tool for consciousness and spiritual experience. It rejects escapism and emphasizes active, conscious participation in life, including embracing qualities of beauty and expression.
tools: Self-analysis and introspection (identifying wants, analyzing thoughts/feelings)
Affirmation (implied in directing thoughts and feelings)

relevant_quotes.text: He who would know God must first know his own consciousness, which is an aspect of God. In order to know your own consciousness, the first thing you must do is to look into your own heart and find out what it is you think you want, and as a result of this, to study what is happening to you so you can see how you are creating everything that you have--that you yourself built yesterday--and that today is the result of yesterday's thinking, feeling and desiring. It is by becoming attentive to your wants, learning what to do about them, that you will begin to be a conscious co-creator with God.

We must not feel that spirituality is walking about with a solemn face and sighing that one has overcome any desire for physical things--this is not spirituality, it is merely an announcement that one is tired of it all and that one is not participating consciously with the heart and mind in the livingness and flow of life. It is an indication that one is building exactly what one feels.
The Lord of the Universe loves to display. True spirituality does not reside in pompous solemnity, the so-called "spiritual attitude."

You must learn how to release the powers of subconsciousness consciously, and you cannot do this until you consciously know what you want. If you have not fixed yourself a goal, you are, in effect, announcing that you have no focus, and you will not have the drive to do much with your consciousness, with your thinking, with your feeling, with all your powers. Remember that you do not have to learn how to direct subconsciousness or to utilize its powers; you have always done it. What you must learn is how to direct it consciously!
We owe it to ourselves and to life to expect the good things in life. As we eradicate complexes of poverty and insecurity, we too will express that which is adequate and beautiful for us.
It is right to want cosmic illumination; we must want it; we must also have enough humility to know that in order to attain it we must become masters of our minds and hearts.

Every school of thought tells us that it is important to care for the physical vehicle. It is in and through the physical vehicle that consciousness experiences Itself, and if we damage the vehicle by negations, neglect, or incorrect evaluation of life, the vehicle will not experience fully.

critical_analysis.relevance: This text offers a practical, psychologically-grounded approach to esoteric development that predates and informs much of modern New Age and manifestation-focused spirituality. It bridges the gap between traditional occultism and contemporary self-help, emphasizing self-responsibility in creation and the integration of material and spiritual well-being. Its focus on directed consciousness and subconscious power aligns with various occult traditions, particularly those influenced by New Thought and early 20th-century occult psychology.
critical_analysis.target_audience: This work is aimed at individuals interested in personal development, spiritual growth, and the manifestation of desires, particularly those seeking to move beyond passive or escapist spiritual paths. It is suitable for occult aspirants, students of consciousness, and anyone looking to understand and consciously direct their internal and external realities. The emphasis on self-mastery suggests an audience ready for deeper self-exploration and practical application.
